speak.voice: So Emma, we've been talking about implementing analytics solutions using Microsoft Fabric. I'm curious, how can we ensure that we're implementing data modeling best practices as we build our data models in Power BI?

That's a great question, Brian! One tool that can help us with that is the Best Practice Analyzer (BPA) in Tabular Editor. It's a tool that runs a set of rules to identify potential modeling missteps or changes that can improve our model design and performance.
That sounds really useful! Can you tell me more about Tabular Editor and how it can be used to run the BPA?

Absolutely! Tabular Editor is an alternative tool for authoring tabular models for Analysis Services and Power BI. It allows users to easily manipulate tabular models and can be used to quickly edit data models, automate repetitive tasks using scripting, incorporate DevOps with tabular models, and run the BPA rules.
So, the BPA is a set of rules that we can run in Tabular Editor to identify modeling best practices. Can we customize these rules?

To run the BPA, we first need to install Tabular Editor. Then, we download the Best Practice Rules from GitHub and save the file. When we find violations, we can review the objects in violation of the rules and fix them using Tabular Editor. For example, if a column violates the "Don't summarize numeric columns" rule, we can go to the object in Tabular Editor, change the object properties as necessary, and save our changes back to the Model.bim file.

Absolutely! The BPA was designed to enable customization for each organization.
